text: so if I had to give some advice to
undergraduates interested in chemistry I
would say they're probably be two things
I would like to tell you one is read a
lot and number two is get to know people
one make sure you are reading things
other than your textbooks there's a lot
in the textbooks but it's all old
information what you need to know if you
really want to be a graduate student in
chemistry you need to be able to
understand what's important and what's
new so reading things like see any news
which actually does a very good job of
picking out what it is actually
important right now and then from there
probably delve into those papers a
little more and kind of get to know
understand what's what's really going on
number two get to know people chemistry
is a very small world and specifically
get to know a faculty member in your
department get to know them well work in
their lab talk to the grad students in
that lab but at the end of the day you
want to have somebody who really has has
established themselves in chemistry as
an assistant professor or at least or
higher to be able to write you a letter
of recommendation at the end of the day
that really is important my name is
Jason Melvin I'm a fourth-year graduate
student at the University of
Pennsylvania working in the labs of aim
Smith
